contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox prepared food | name = Knish | image = [[File:Lower East Side - Schimmel Knish 2.jpg|250px]] | caption = A classic potato knish | alternate_name = Knysh | country = | region = | creator = | course = | type = [[Snack]], [[Side Dish]] | served = | main_ingredient = [[Mashed potato]]es, ground meat, [[sauerkraut]], [[onion]]s, [[kasha]] or [[cheese]] | variations = | calories = | other = }} A '''knish''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|n|ɪ|ʃ}} or '''knysh''' is an [[Eastern European]],<ref name=reformknish>{{cite journal|url=http://reformjudaismmag.org/Articles/index.cfm?id=1537|work=Reform Judaism Magazine|author=Wasserman, Tina|title=Cooking: The Ultimate Jewish Finger Food|accessdate=2010-09-14}}</ref> and [[Jewish]] snack food made popular in North America by [[Eastern European]] immigrants, eaten widely by both Jewish and non-Jewish people.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} ==History== Eastern European immigrants who arrived sometime around 1900 brought knishes to North America.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=AoWlCmNDA3QC&lpg=PT359&ots=sSSAFjbBPT&dq=origin%20of%20knish%20ukraine&pg=PT359#v=onepage&q=origin%20of%20knish%20ukraine&f=false |title=The Oxford Companion to American Food and Drink - Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-21}}</ref> Knish (קניש) is a Yiddish word that was derived from the Ukrainian or Russian "knysh" (Книш), meaning dumpling or cake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewfaq.org/food.htm |title=Judaism 101: Jewish Cooking |publisher=Jewfaq.org |date= |accessdate=2013-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/knish |title=knish - definition of knish by the Free Online Dictionary, Thesaurus and Encyclopedia |publisher=Thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-21}}</ref> The first knish bakery was founded in New York in 1910."<ref>(Kugel, Knishes, and Other Tasty Dishes by Nina Yellin, 2001)</ref> Generally recognized as a food made popular in New York by immigrants in the early 1900s, the United States underwent a knish renaissance in the 2000s driven by knish specialty establishments such as the Knish Shop in Baltimore, Maryland,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishinbaltimore.com/The-Knish-Shop.html |title=The Knish Shop, Baltimore |publisher=Jewishinbaltimore.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-21}}</ref> Buffalo and Bergen<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonian.com/blogs/bestbites/food-restaurant-news/524-gina-chersevanis-union-market-soda-shop-and-bar-will-be-called-buffalo-and-bergen.php |title=Gina Chersevani's Union Market Soda Shop and Bar Will Be Called Buffalo and Bergen | Food & Restaurant News |publisher=Washingtonian |date=2012-05-24 |accessdate=2013-01-21}}</ref> in Washington, DC, or My Mother's Knish,<ref>{{cite web|author=By Alan RichmanPhotograph by Martin O'Neill |url=http://www.gq.com/food-travel/alan-richman/200602/ida-richman-knish-kitchen-family |title=A Mother's Knishes: Alan Richman |publisher=GQ |date= |accessdate=2013-01-21}}</ref> in Westlake Village, California. A knish consists of a [[filling (cooking)|filling]] covered with [[dough]] that is either [[baking|baked]], [[grilling|grilled]], or [[deep frying|deep fried]]. Knishes can be purchased from [[street vendor]]s in urban areas with a large Jewish population, sometimes at a [[hot dog stand]] or from a butcher shop. In the most East European traditional versions, the filling is made entirely of [[mashed potato]], ground meat, [[sauerkraut]], [[onion]]s, [[kasha]] ([[buckwheat]] groats), or [[cheese]]. Other varieties of fillings include [[sweet potatoes]], [[black beans]], [[fruit]], [[broccoli]], [[tofu]], or [[spinach]]. Many cultures have variations of baked, grilled, or fried dough-covered snacks to which epicurean family the knish belongs including the [[Pasty|Cornish pasty]], the Scottish [[Bridie]], the [[Jamaican patty]], the Spanish and Latin American [[empanada]], the Middle Eastern [[fatayer]], the Portuguese ''rissol'' ([[rissole]]), the Italian [[calzone]], the Indian [[samosa]], the Polish [[pierogi]], the Russian [[Pirozhki]], and the Ukrainian Pyrizhky. Knishes may be round, rectangular, or square. They may be entirely covered in dough or some of the filling may peek out of the top. Sizes range from those that can be eaten in a single bite [[hors d'oeuvre]] to [[sandwich]]-sized. ==See also== {{Wiktionary|knish|קניש}} *[[Turnover (food)|Turnover]] *[[Jewish food]] *[[Pirozhki]] * [[List of Russian dishes]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Potato dishes}} {{Dumplings}} [[Category:Jewish cuisine]] [[Category:Dumplings]] [[Category:Savoury pies]] [[Category:Potato dishes]] [[Category:Russian cuisine]] [[Category:Slavic cuisine]] [[Category:Street food]] {{Jewish-cuisine-stub}}
